Comments_List: Better understanding of some issues, both on a big picture level and on more technical details.

- Importance of method/data used when quantifying current and historic levels of inequality
- The ways that housing, education, money in politics, infrastructure, etc. both reflect and contribute to inequality
- Impossible to separate the policy and politics of inequality
The class was at its best when discussions were well-framed and lectures well-structured.

Strengths:
- Strong syllabus and reading list
- Profs Shapiro & Graetz clearly knowledgable 
- Interesting mix of undergrads, law students, phds, and other masters students 

Weaknesses:
- Would have enjoyed more dynamic class discussion
I would recommend this course to someone who was aggressive in their demeanor and who is interested in pragmatic approaches to tackling inequality.
